docs.title: Zero-to-Pro Developer Roadmap
docs.text:
Welcome! Start with the 00 — Git Path, then pick a track. This site is auto-generated from the repository catalog.

Start here

1) Do the 00 — Git Path 2) Pick a track from Tracks → Overview 3) Open a Progress Tracker issue (template provided)

– 👉 Tracks Overview – 🧰 Start Git: 00 — Git Path (repo) – ✅ Create progress issue: https://github.com/AyhamJo7/Zero-2-Pro/issues/new?template=progress.md&title=Progress%3A+YOUR_NAME

  • 📚 Tracks: See the Tracks Overview
  • 🧭 Repository: GitHub Repo
  • 🧩 Contributing: See CONTRIBUTING.md in the repo

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text: High-level, human-friendly changes. For details, see Git history.

docs.title: Unreleased
docs.text: • …

• Initial docs site with auto-generated track pages
  • TOC generator and catalog validator

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • [ ] Master Core Web Vitals (LCP, FID, CLS) measurement and optimization
  • [ ] Implement advanced bundling and code splitting strategies
  • [ ] Set up comprehensive performance monitoring
  • [ ] Apply scalable performance optimization techniques

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Completion of web-03-project-spa-api
  • Strong understanding of modern JavaScript and web APIs
  • Experience with build tools and CI/CD

docs.title: Part 1: Core Web Vitals Deep Dive
docs.text: TODO: Create detailed content on measuring and optimizing LCP, FID, and CLS

docs.title: Part 2: Advanced Bundling & Code Splitting
docs.text: TODO: Add comprehensive guide to Webpack/Vite optimization, tree shaking, and dynamic imports

docs.title: Part 3: Performance Budgets & Monitoring
docs.text: TODO: Implement Lighthouse CI, bundle analyzers, and performance tracking

docs.title: Part 4: Observability at Scale
docs.text: TODO: Set up RUM, error tracking, and performance dashboards

docs.title: Final Project
docs.text: Build a production-ready web application that: - Achieves excellent Core Web Vitals scores - Implements intelligent code splitting - Includes comprehensive performance monitoring - Demonstrates measurable optimization improvements

docs.title: Assessment Criteria
docs.text:
• Performance metrics meet industry standards
  • Monitoring setup provides actionable insights
  • Code demonstrates advanced optimization techniques
  • Documentation includes performance analysis

docs.title: Resources & References
docs.text:
TODO: Add links to performance tools, case studies, and best practices

This is an advanced module requiring significant hands-on practice with real-world performance challenges.

docs.title: Web Development Level-3 Challenges
docs.text: These stretch challenges extend the web-03-project-spa-api milestone with additional complexity and real-world scenarios.

docs.title: Challenge 1: Progressive Web App (PWA)
docs.text:
Transform your SPA into a full PWA with:

  • Service worker for offline functionality
  • App manifest for installability
  • Push notifications integration
  • Background sync capabilities

Skills developed: Service workers, PWA APIs, offline-first design

docs.title: Challenge 2: Advanced Authentication
docs.text:
Extend authentication with:

  • OAuth2 integration (Google, GitHub)
  • Multi-factor authentication (TOTP)
  • Role-based access control (RBAC)
  • Session management and refresh tokens

Skills developed: OAuth flows, security patterns, token management

docs.title: Challenge 3: Real-time Features
docs.text:
Add real-time capabilities:

  • WebSocket integration for live updates
  • Real-time collaboration features
  • Server-sent events for notifications
  • Optimistic UI updates

Skills developed: WebSockets, real-time patterns, state synchronization

docs.title: Challenge 4: Performance & Monitoring
docs.text:
Implement production-ready optimizations:

  • Code splitting and lazy loading
  • Performance budgets and monitoring
  • Error tracking and logging
  • Analytics and user behavior tracking

Skills developed: Performance optimization, observability, analytics

docs.title: Challenge 5: Deployment & DevOps
docs.text:
Set up production deployment pipeline:

  • Docker containerization
  • CI/CD pipeline with automated tests
  • Environment management (dev/staging/prod)
  • Database migrations and backups

Skills developed: Docker, CI/CD, deployment strategies, infrastructure

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Choose 2-3 challenges that interest you most
  2. Fork or extend your existing web-03 project
  3. Document your implementation approach
  4. Submit your enhanced project for peer review

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• PWA Documentation
  • OAuth2 Specification
  • WebSocket API
  • Web Performance Best Practices

docs.title: Advanced: Async IO, Concurrency, and Profiling
Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • [ ] Master asyncio event loops, coroutines, and concurrent patterns
  • [ ] Implement high-throughput async applications
  • [ ] Profile Python applications and identify bottlenecks
  • [ ] Apply advanced optimization techniques

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Completion of py-03-project-cli
  • Solid understanding of Python fundamentals
  • Experience with testing and packaging

docs.title: Part 1: Asyncio Foundations
docs.text: TODO: Deep dive into event loops, coroutines, tasks, and futures

docs.title: Part 2: Concurrent Patterns
docs.text: TODO: Producer-consumer, worker pools, semaphores, and backpressure handling

docs.title: Part 3: Performance Profiling
docs.text: TODO: cProfile, line_profiler, memory_profiler, and optimization strategies

docs.title: Part 4: Advanced Optimization
docs.text: TODO: Cython, numba, and when to drop to C extensions

docs.title: Final Project
docs.text: Build a high-performance async web scraper or data processor that: - Handles thousands of concurrent requests - Implements proper backpressure and rate limiting - Includes comprehensive profiling and optimization - Demonstrates measurable performance improvements

docs.title: Assessment Criteria
docs.text:
• Proper async/await usage and error handling
  • Efficient resource utilization under load
  • Evidence-based performance optimization
  • Clean, maintainable concurrent code

docs.title: Resources & References
docs.text:
TODO: Add links to asyncio guides, profiling tools, and performance case studies

This module focuses on building high-performance Python applications that scale effectively.

docs.title: Python Level-3 Challenges
docs.text: These stretch challenges extend the py-03-project-cli milestone with advanced Python concepts and real-world applications.

docs.title: Challenge 1: Async CLI Tool
docs.text:
Convert your CLI to async patterns:

  • Async HTTP requests and file I/O
  • Concurrent task execution
  • Progress bars for long-running operations
  • Graceful cancellation handling

Skills developed: asyncio, concurrent programming, user experience

docs.title: Challenge 2: Plugin Architecture
docs.text:
Add extensible plugin system:

  • Dynamic plugin loading and discovery
  • Plugin API design and documentation
  • Configuration management for plugins
  • Plugin lifecycle management

Skills developed: Dynamic imports, API design, extensibility patterns

docs.title: Challenge 3: Advanced Data Processing
docs.text:
Implement high-performance data handling:

  • Stream processing for large datasets
  • Memory-efficient algorithms
  • Integration with pandas/numpy
  • Data validation and transformation pipelines

Skills developed: Stream processing, data science libraries, algorithms

docs.title: Challenge 4: Distributed Processing
docs.text:
Add distributed computing capabilities:

  • Message queue integration (Redis/RabbitMQ)
  • Worker processes with task distribution
  • Result aggregation and monitoring
  • Fault tolerance and retry mechanisms

Skills developed: Message queues, distributed systems, fault tolerance

docs.title: Challenge 5: Production Deployment
docs.text:
Package for production distribution:

  • Docker containerization with multi-stage builds
  • PyPI package publication
  • CI/CD with automated testing
  • Cross-platform compatibility testing

Skills developed: Packaging, distribution, CI/CD, containerization

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Select 2-3 challenges aligned with your interests
  2. Extend your existing py-03 CLI project
  3. Document design decisions and trade-offs
  4. Create comprehensive tests for new features

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• asyncio Documentation
  • Python Packaging Guide
  • Celery for Distributed Tasks
  • Docker Best Practices

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • [ ] Implement circuit breakers, retries, and timeout patterns
  • [ ] Set up metrics, tracing, and logging for production services
  • [ ] Handle distributed system failures gracefully
  • [ ] Apply chaos engineering principles

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Completion of java-03-project-service
  • Understanding of REST APIs and Spring Boot
  • Basic knowledge of distributed systems

docs.title: Part 1: Resilience Patterns
docs.text: TODO: Circuit breakers, bulkheads, timeouts, and retry strategies

docs.title: Part 2: Observability Stack
docs.text: TODO: Metrics with Micrometer, tracing with Zipkin, structured logging

docs.title: Part 3: Production Readiness
docs.text: TODO: Health checks, graceful shutdown, configuration management

docs.title: Part 4: Chaos Engineering
docs.text: TODO: Fault injection, load testing, and failure scenario testing

docs.title: Final Project
docs.text: Build a resilient microservice that: - Implements multiple resilience patterns - Provides comprehensive observability - Handles various failure scenarios gracefully - Includes chaos engineering tests

docs.title: Assessment Criteria
docs.text:
• Proper implementation of resilience patterns
  • Comprehensive monitoring and alerting
  • Evidence of failure scenario testing
  • Production-ready configuration and deployment

docs.title: Resources & References
docs.text:
TODO: Add links to Spring Cloud, resilience libraries, and observability tools

This module prepares you to build and operate resilient services in production environments.

docs.title: Java Level-3 Challenges
docs.text: These stretch challenges extend the java-03-project-service milestone with enterprise Java patterns and technologies.

docs.title: Challenge 1: Microservices Architecture
docs.text:
Decompose your service into microservices:

  • Service discovery and registration
  • Inter-service communication patterns
  • Distributed configuration management
  • Circuit breaker implementation

Skills developed: Microservices patterns, Spring Cloud, resilience

docs.title: Challenge 2: Event-Driven Architecture
docs.text:
Implement event-driven patterns:

  • Message brokers (Apache Kafka, RabbitMQ)
  • Event sourcing and CQRS patterns
  • Saga pattern for distributed transactions
  • Event streaming and processing

Skills developed: Event sourcing, message brokers, distributed transactions

docs.title: Challenge 3: Advanced Data Persistence
docs.text:
Enhance data layer capabilities:

  • Multi-database support (SQL + NoSQL)
  • Connection pooling and optimization
  • Database migration strategies
  • Caching layers (Redis, Caffeine)

Skills developed: Database design, caching strategies, data access patterns

docs.title: Challenge 4: Security & Compliance
docs.text:
Implement enterprise security:

  • OAuth2 and JWT token management
  • Role-based access control (RBAC)
  • Input validation and sanitization
  • Audit logging and compliance

Skills developed: Security frameworks, compliance, authentication

docs.title: Challenge 5: Performance & Monitoring
docs.text:
Add production-ready observability:

  • Application performance monitoring (APM)
  • Custom metrics and dashboards
  • JVM tuning and garbage collection
  • Load testing and profiling

Skills developed: Performance tuning, JVM internals, monitoring tools

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Choose 2-3 challenges that match your career goals
  2. Build upon your existing java-03 service
  3. Document architecture decisions
  4. Implement comprehensive testing strategy

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• Spring Cloud Documentation
  • Apache Kafka Guide
  • Java Security Architecture
  • JVM Performance Tuning

docs.title: Advanced: Concurrency Patterns, Context, and Backpressure
Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • [ ] Apply advanced concurrency patterns (worker pools, fan-in/out, pipelines)
  • [ ] Master context.Context for cancellation and timeouts
  • [ ] Implement backpressure and flow control mechanisms
  • [ ] Build scalable concurrent systems

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Completion of go-03-project-service
  • Strong understanding of goroutines and channels
  • Experience with HTTP services in Go

docs.title: Part 1: Advanced Concurrency Patterns
docs.text: TODO: Worker pools, pipelines, fan-in/fan-out, and select patterns

docs.title: Part 2: Context Mastery
docs.text: TODO: Context propagation, cancellation, deadlines, and values

docs.title: Part 3: Backpressure & Flow Control
docs.text: TODO: Rate limiting, buffering strategies, and graceful degradation

docs.title: Part 4: Performance & Profiling
docs.text: TODO: pprof, benchmarking, and optimization techniques

docs.title: Final Project
docs.text: Build a high-throughput data processing service that: - Processes thousands of concurrent requests - Implements proper context handling and cancellation - Includes backpressure and flow control - Demonstrates measurable performance characteristics

docs.title: Assessment Criteria
docs.text:
• Effective use of advanced concurrency patterns
  • Proper context usage throughout the application
  • Robust backpressure handling under load
  • Evidence-based performance optimization

docs.title: Resources & References
docs.text:

This module focuses on building highly concurrent Go applications that perform well under load.

docs.title: Go Level-3 Challenges
docs.text: These stretch challenges extend the go-03-project-service milestone with advanced Go patterns and distributed systems concepts.

docs.title: Challenge 1: gRPC Service Architecture
docs.text:
Transform your HTTP service to gRPC:

  • Protocol buffer definitions and code generation
  • Streaming RPC implementations
  • Service discovery and load balancing
  • Inter-service communication patterns

Skills developed: gRPC, protocol buffers, streaming, service mesh

docs.title: Challenge 2: High-Performance Concurrency
docs.text:
Optimize for extreme concurrency:

  • Worker pools with backpressure handling
  • Lock-free data structures where appropriate
  • Context-based cancellation patterns
  • Memory pool optimizations

Skills developed: Advanced concurrency, performance optimization, profiling

docs.title: Challenge 3: Cloud-Native Deployment
docs.text:
Build for cloud-native environments:

  • Kubernetes deployment manifests
  • Health checks and readiness probes
  • Configuration management with ConfigMaps
  • Service mesh integration (Istio)

Skills developed: Kubernetes, cloud-native patterns, service mesh

docs.title: Challenge 4: Observability & Monitoring
docs.text:
Implement comprehensive observability:

  • Structured logging with structured data
  • Distributed tracing with OpenTelemetry
  • Custom metrics and alerting
  • Performance profiling integration

Skills developed: Observability tools, tracing, metrics, profiling

docs.title: Challenge 5: Data Pipeline Processing
docs.text:
Build high-throughput data processing:

  • Stream processing with Apache Kafka
  • ETL pipelines with proper error handling
  • Batch processing with concurrency
  • Data validation and transformation

Skills developed: Stream processing, data pipelines, message brokers

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Select challenges that align with your interests
  2. Extend your go-03 service with chosen enhancements
  3. Focus on Go idioms and best practices
  4. Benchmark and profile your implementations

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• gRPC-Go Documentation
  • Kubernetes Go Client
  • OpenTelemetry Go
  • Go Performance Optimization

docs.title: Advanced: RAG Evaluation, Guardrails, and Observability
Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • [ ] Design and implement RAG evaluation pipelines
  • [ ] Build safety guardrails and content filtering systems
  • [ ] Set up comprehensive ML observability
  • [ ] Handle production ML system challenges

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Completion of ai-03-project-mlapp
  • Understanding of LLMs and RAG patterns
  • Experience with ML evaluation metrics

docs.title: Part 1: RAG Evaluation Frameworks
docs.text: TODO: Retrieval metrics, generation quality, end-to-end evaluation

docs.title: Part 2: Safety & Guardrails
docs.text: TODO: Content filtering, bias detection, prompt injection prevention

docs.title: Part 3: ML Observability
docs.text: TODO: Model monitoring, drift detection, performance tracking

docs.title: Part 4: Production Challenges
docs.text: TODO: Scaling, cost optimization, and model lifecycle management

docs.title: Final Project
docs.text: Build a production-ready RAG system that: - Includes comprehensive evaluation metrics - Implements safety guardrails and content filtering - Provides full observability and monitoring - Demonstrates handling of production challenges

docs.title: Assessment Criteria
docs.text:
• Robust evaluation framework with relevant metrics
  • Effective safety measures and guardrails
  • Comprehensive monitoring and alerting
  • Evidence of production readiness

docs.title: Resources & References

This module prepares you to deploy and maintain AI/ML systems in production environments.

docs.title: AI/ML Level-3 Challenges
docs.text: These stretch challenges extend the ai-03-project-mlapp milestone with advanced AI/ML techniques and production considerations.

docs.title: Challenge 1: Advanced RAG Pipeline
docs.text:
Enhance your RAG system with:

  • Multi-modal retrieval (text, images, code)
  • Hybrid search (dense + sparse retrieval)
  • Re-ranking and query expansion
  • Conversational memory and context management

Skills developed: Advanced retrieval, multi-modal AI, conversation design

docs.title: Challenge 2: Model Fine-tuning & Optimization
docs.text:
Implement custom model improvements:

  • Fine-tuning on domain-specific data
  • Model quantization and compression
  • ONNX export and optimization
  • A/B testing for model variants

Skills developed: Model customization, optimization techniques, experimentation

docs.title: Challenge 3: MLOps Pipeline
docs.text:
Build production ML infrastructure:

  • Model versioning and registry
  • Automated training and evaluation pipelines
  • Model deployment with blue/green strategies
  • Drift detection and retraining triggers

Skills developed: MLOps, model lifecycle, automation, monitoring

docs.title: Challenge 4: AI Safety & Ethics
docs.text:
Implement responsible AI practices:

  • Bias detection and mitigation strategies
  • Content filtering and safety guardrails
  • Explainability and interpretability tools
  • Privacy-preserving techniques

Skills developed: AI ethics, safety engineering, interpretability

docs.title: Challenge 5: Scalable AI Infrastructure
docs.text:
Deploy at production scale:

  • GPU optimization and batching strategies
  • Model serving with auto-scaling
  • Cost optimization and resource management
  • Multi-model serving architecture

Skills developed: Infrastructure scaling, cost optimization, resource management

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Choose challenges that match your AI/ML interests
  2. Build upon your ai-03 project foundation
  3. Focus on measurable improvements and metrics
  4. Document evaluation methodologies and results

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• Hugging Face Transformers
  • MLflow Documentation
  • ONNX Runtime
  • Responsible AI Practices

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will:

  • [ ] Develop systematic security hardening procedures
  • [ ] Conduct comprehensive threat modeling exercises
  • [ ] Implement layered security controls
  • [ ] Design incident response and monitoring systems

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Completion of sec-03-project-harden-app
  • Strong understanding of security fundamentals
  • Experience with security tools and practices

docs.title: Part 1: Security Hardening Playbooks
docs.text: TODO: Systematic hardening procedures for different environments and technologies

docs.title: Part 2: Threat Modeling Methodologies
docs.text: TODO: STRIDE, attack trees, and risk assessment frameworks

docs.title: Part 3: Defense-in-Depth Implementation
docs.text: TODO: Multiple security layers, controls, and monitoring integration

docs.title: Part 4: Incident Response & Monitoring
docs.text: TODO: Detection, response procedures, and forensic considerations

docs.title: Final Project
docs.text: Create a comprehensive security framework that: - Includes detailed hardening playbooks - Demonstrates systematic threat modeling - Implements multiple security controls - Provides incident response procedures

docs.title: Assessment Criteria
docs.text:
• Thorough and practical hardening procedures
  • Systematic threat modeling approach
  • Effective layered security implementation
  • Realistic incident response planning

docs.title: Resources & References
docs.text:

This module focuses on building comprehensive security programs for organizations and systems.

docs.title: Cyber Security Level-3 Challenges
docs.text: These stretch challenges extend the sec-03-project-harden-app milestone with advanced security concepts and real-world scenarios.

docs.title: Challenge 1: Advanced Threat Detection
docs.text:
Implement sophisticated detection mechanisms:

  • SIEM integration and log analysis
  • Behavioral anomaly detection
  • Machine learning for threat classification
  • Threat intelligence integration

Skills developed: SIEM tools, anomaly detection, threat intelligence

docs.title: Challenge 2: Zero Trust Architecture
docs.text:
Design and implement zero trust principles:

  • Identity and access management (IAM)
  • Micro-segmentation strategies
  • Continuous authentication and authorization
  • Device compliance and attestation

Skills developed: Zero trust principles, IAM, network security

docs.title: Challenge 3: Incident Response Automation
docs.text:
Build automated response capabilities:

  • Security orchestration and automated response (SOAR)
  • Playbook automation for common incidents
  • Threat hunting automation
  • Integration with security tools and APIs

Skills developed: Security automation, incident response, tool integration

docs.title: Challenge 4: Advanced Penetration Testing
docs.text:
Develop comprehensive testing methodology:

  • Automated vulnerability scanning integration
  • Custom exploit development (ethical, controlled)
  • Social engineering assessment frameworks
  • Red team exercise planning and execution

Skills developed: Penetration testing, vulnerability assessment, red teaming

docs.title: Challenge 5: Compliance & Risk Management
docs.text:
Implement comprehensive compliance framework:

  • GDPR, HIPAA, or SOC2 compliance implementation
  • Risk assessment and management procedures
  • Security metrics and KPI tracking
  • Third-party security assessment processes

Skills developed: Compliance frameworks, risk management, security governance

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Select challenges aligned with your security career path
  2. Extend your sec-03 hardening project
  3. Always operate within legal and ethical boundaries
  4. Document security controls and their effectiveness

docs.title: Important Notice
docs.text:
All security challenges must be performed in controlled, legal environments:

  • Use dedicated lab environments only
  • Never test on systems you don't own
  • Follow responsible disclosure practices
  • Comply with local laws and regulations

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• OWASP Testing Guide
  • NIST Cybersecurity Framework
  • SANS Security Resources
  • MITRE ATT&CK Framework

docs.title: Level Rubric (0–4)
docs.text: Use this rubric to set expectations for each module's depth and outcomes.

docs.title: Level 0 — Zero (Orientation & Setup)
docs.text:
Purpose: Get from nothing to a working environment and basic mental models. Evidence: Screenshots, CLI output, short reflection, or repo with trivial code.

Checklist - [ ] Environment installed and verified - [ ] Key terms defined in learner's own words - [ ] First "hello world" or equivalent - [ ] Short reflection: what I learned / where I got stuck

docs.title: Level 1 — Foundations (Syntax & Basics)
docs.text:
Purpose: Core vocabulary of the domain. Evidence: Small exercises that touch most primitives.

Checklist - [ ] At least 3 concrete outcomes demonstrated - [ ] Exercises cover input/output, basic control flow or equivalents - [ ] Simple error handling or debugging step - [ ] Assessment includes a deliverable link (repo/gist)

docs.title: Level 2 — Core Skills (Real-World Tasks)
docs.text:
Purpose: Combine fundamentals into practical workflows. Evidence: Mini-projects or tasks mirroring real usage.

Checklist - [ ] Uses tooling, testing, or validation - [ ] Performs I/O, persistence, or network call (domain-appropriate) - [ ] Includes README with run/test instructions - [ ] Assessment has a rubric reference

docs.title: Level 3 — Projects (Portfolio)
docs.text:
Purpose: Build something end-to-end with scope, constraints, and review. Evidence: Public repo with docs, tests (where relevant), and demo.

Checklist - [ ] Clear acceptance criteria - [ ] CI or basic automation - [ ] Tradeoff discussion in README - [ ] Demo artifact (link, GIF, screenshots)

docs.title: Level 4 — Advanced (Depth/Specialization)
docs.text:
Purpose: Performance, scale, security, architecture, or advanced patterns. Evidence: Benchmarks, profiles, security posture, or architecture write-up.

Checklist - [ ] Measurable improvement or depth (e.g., perf/security) - [ ] Reproducible experiments or load tests (domain-appropriate) - [ ] Documented methodology and results - [ ] Reflection on limitations and next steps

docs.title: Project Rubric (Milestone Modules)
docs.text:
Use this for Level-3 "Milestone Projects". Score 0–3 each; total /24.

Criterion 0 – Not Met 1 – Partial 2 – Meets 3 – Exceeds Scope & Requirements Missing major requirements Some requirements unclear or missing All requirements implemented Adds well-documented, sensible extras Correctness Frequent errors; fails basic cases Works for common paths, edge cases fail Passes defined scenarios & edge cases Includes additional tests/specs; robust to unexpected input Code Quality Disorganized; unclear structure Some structure; inconsistent style Clear modules, consistent style, comments Exceptional readability; thoughtful abstractions Testing/Validation None Minimal checks Unit/integration tests or validation present High coverage; CI runs tests automatically Documentation Missing or minimal Basic README with run steps Clear README (setup, run, test, decisions) Architecture diagram, tradeoffs, future work DevEx/Automation Hard to run; manual steps Some scripts Scripts or Makefile; CI lint/checks Full CI, pre-commit hooks, reproducible env

Passing Guidance - Pass: ≥ 12/24 and no zeros on Correctness or Scope. - Merit: ≥ 18/24. - Distinction: ≥ 22/24 and at least two 3's.

docs.title: Submission Template
docs.text:
• Repo URL:
  • Short demo (link/GIF):
  • What works / what doesn't:
  • Time spent & main challenges:
  • Next steps (if continuing):

docs.title: Review Notes
docs.text:
• Reviewers leave line comments + a summary referencing this rubric.
  • If requested changes are minor, allow resubmission without full re-review.

docs.title: Zero-to-Pro Learning Roadmap
docs.text: From Zero to Production-Ready Skills - A comprehensive, hands-on learning path for software development.

docs.title: 🎯 What You'll Build
docs.text:
• Level 0: Setup and orientation
  • Level 1: Foundation concepts
  • Level 2: Core practical skills
  • Level 3: Real-world project milestones
  • Level 4: Advanced production techniques

docs.title: 🚀 Available Tracks
docs.text:
Choose your learning path:

  • Web Development - HTML, CSS, JavaScript, APIs, and full-stack development
  • Python - From basics to advanced Python programming
  • Java - Object-oriented programming and enterprise development
  • Go - Systems programming and concurrent applications
  • AI/ML - Machine learning and AI application development
  • Cyber Security - Security fundamentals and defensive practices

docs.title: 🏁 Get Started
docs.text:
1. Quick Start Guide - Set up in 10 minutes
  2. Choose a track based on your interests and goals
  3. Start with Level 0 and progress at your own pace
  4. Join the community for support and collaboration

docs.title: 🤝 Community
docs.text:
• Progress Dashboard - See who's learning what
  • Showcase - Share your projects and achievements
  • Discussions - Ask questions and help others

Ready to go from zero to pro? Start here →

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with Zero-to-Pro in 10 minutes! This guide covers everything you need to start learning.

docs.title: 🎯 Choose Your Path
docs.text:
New to programming? Start here: - Git Fundamentals → Web Development

Have programming experience? Jump to: - Python Track • Java Track • Go Track

Interested in AI/ML or Security? - AI/ML Track • Cyber Security Track

docs.title: Step 1: Development Environment
docs.text:
Choose one option:

=== "GitHub Codespaces (Recommended)"

1. **Fork this repository** on GitHub
2. **Click "Code" → "Create codespace on main"**
3. **Wait 2-3 minutes** for automatic setup
4. **You're ready!** All tools pre-installed

=== "Local Setup"

1. **Install Git**: [Download here](https://git-scm.com/)
2. **Clone repository**:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/Zero-2-Pro.git
   cd Zero-2-Pro
   ```
3. **Install Node.js**: [Download v20](https://nodejs.org/)
4. **Install dependencies**:
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

=== "VS Code Dev Container"

1. **Install VS Code** and **Docker Desktop**
2. **Install Dev Containers extension**
3. **Clone and open** repository in VS Code
4. **Click "Reopen in Container"** when prompted
5. **Wait for container build** (5-10 minutes first time)

docs.title: Step 2: Verify Setup
docs.text:
Run these commands to ensure everything works:

# Validate catalog and build TOC
npm run check

# Start local documentation server
npm run site:serve

Visit http://localhost:8000 to see the site running locally.

docs.title: Step 3: Pick Your First Module
docs.text:
Based on your background:

Complete Beginner:

# Start with Git basics
open docs/00-git-path/git-01-intro.md

Some Programming Experience:

# Jump to a specific track
open docs/01-web-development/web-00-orientation.md
open docs/02-python/py-00-setup.md

Experienced Developer:

# Go straight to Level 2 modules
open docs/01-web-development/web-02-core-fullstack.md

docs.title: 🚀 Next Steps
docs.text:
You're all set! Here's what to do now:

  1. Choose your track based on your goals
  2. Join the community and introduce yourself
  3. Create progress issue to track your journey
  4. Start learning! Remember: consistency beats intensity

Happy learning! 🎉

docs.title: Community Showcase
docs.text: Celebrate your learning journey and inspire others! This showcase highlights outstanding projects, learning stories, and contributions from the Zero-to-Pro community.

docs.title: Featured Projects
docs.text: This section will grow as community members submit their work. Be the first to share!

docs.title: How to Add Your Project
docs.text:
To feature your project here:

  1. Complete a Zero-to-Pro module or track milestone
  2. Build something awesome using what you learned
  3. Document your project with README, demos, or blog posts
  4. Submit a showcase PR using the template below

docs.title: Showcase Submission Template
docs.text:
### Project Name

**Creator:** [@YourGitHub](https://github.com/yourgithub) • [LinkedIn](optional) • [Portfolio](optional)

**Track/Module:** Which Zero-to-Pro content you used (e.g., "Web Development Level 3")

**Description:** 1-2 sentences about what you built and why

**Tech Stack:** Key technologies used

**Links:** 
- 🔗 [Live Demo](https://your-project.com)
- 📂 [Source Code](https://github.com/you/project)
- 📝 [Blog Post](optional)

**What You Learned:** Brief note about your key takeaways

**Screenshot/Demo:**
![Project Screenshot](link-to-image)

docs.title: Your Turn!
docs.text:
Ready to showcase your work?

  1. Build something using Zero-to-Pro content
  2. Document it properly with README and demo
  3. Submit using our template above
  4. Celebrate your learning achievement! 🎉

Questions? Open a discussion with the "showcase" tag.

docs.title: Level Rubric
docs.text: This rubric defines the expectations for each learning level in Zero-to-Pro tracks.

docs.title: Level 0: Orientation (Setup & Introduction)
docs.text:
Purpose: Get oriented and set up your development environment

Duration: 1-3 days

Requirements: - Install necessary tools and software - Understand basic concepts and terminology - Complete environment verification - Familiarize yourself with track structure

Assessment: Setup verification and basic concept understanding

docs.title: Level 1: Foundations (Core Concepts)
docs.text:
Purpose: Learn fundamental concepts and syntax

Duration: 1-2 weeks

Requirements: - Understand core language or domain concepts - Complete basic exercises and examples - Demonstrate fundamental syntax knowledge - Build simple, working examples

Assessment: Exercises demonstrating basic proficiency

docs.title: Level 2: Core Skills (Practical Application)
docs.text:
Purpose: Apply knowledge to practical scenarios

Duration: 2-3 weeks

Requirements: - Integrate multiple concepts together - Use standard tools and best practices - Handle common real-world scenarios - Demonstrate problem-solving ability

Assessment: Projects requiring integration of multiple skills

docs.title: Level 3: Project Milestone (Real-world Application)
docs.text:
Purpose: Build substantial, portfolio-worthy projects

Duration: 3-4 weeks

Requirements: - Plan and execute a significant project - Apply professional development practices - Include testing, documentation, and deployment - Demonstrate production-ready thinking

Assessment: Complete project with professional standards

docs.title: Level 4: Advanced Topics (Production Expertise)
docs.text:
Purpose: Master advanced concepts for production environments

Duration: 3-6 weeks

Requirements: - Handle complex, production-scale challenges - Demonstrate deep understanding of advanced concepts - Apply best practices for scalability and maintenance - Contribute to or mentor others in the community

Assessment: Advanced projects demonstrating expertise

docs.title: Quality Standards
docs.text: All Levels Must Include: - Clear learning objectives - Hands-on practice opportunities - Self-assessment mechanisms - Resource links and references - Next steps and progression paths

docs.title: Project Rubric
docs.text: This rubric defines quality standards for Zero-to-Pro projects, particularly Level-3 milestone projects.

docs.title: Excellent (90-100%)
docs.text:
• Code is clean, well-structured, and follows language conventions
  • Proper error handling and edge case management
  • Efficient algorithms and data structures
  • Security considerations implemented
  • Performance optimized where appropriate

docs.title: Good (80-89%)
docs.text:
• Code is mostly clean with minor structural issues
  • Basic error handling implemented
  • Standard algorithms and approaches used
  • Some security considerations present
  • Adequate performance for intended use

docs.title: Satisfactory (70-79%)
docs.text:
• Code works but may have structural problems
  • Minimal error handling
  • Basic implementation without optimization
  • Limited security considerations
  • Performance acceptable for basic use

docs.title: Needs Improvement (Below 70%)
docs.text:
• Code has significant structural or functional issues
  • Poor or missing error handling
  • Inefficient or incorrect implementation
  • Security vulnerabilities present
  • Poor performance or reliability

docs.title: Excellent (90-100%)
docs.text:
• Comprehensive README with clear setup instructions
  • Code comments where necessary
  • API documentation if applicable
  • Usage examples and screenshots
  • Contribution guidelines for open projects

docs.title: Good (80-89%)
docs.text:
• Good README with setup instructions
  • Some code comments
  • Basic usage documentation
  • Examples provided

docs.title: Satisfactory (70-79%)
docs.text:
• Basic README present
  • Minimal comments
  • Setup instructions may be unclear
  • Limited examples

docs.title: Needs Improvement (Below 70%)
docs.text:
• Poor or missing documentation
  • No clear setup instructions
  • Difficult to understand project purpose or usage

docs.title: Excellent (90-100%)
docs.text:
• Comprehensive test coverage (>80%)
  • Unit tests for core functionality
  • Integration tests where appropriate
  • Edge case testing
  • Automated test runner configured

docs.title: Good (80-89%)
docs.text:
• Good test coverage (60-80%)
  • Unit tests for main features
  • Basic integration testing
  • Test runner configured

docs.title: Satisfactory (70-79%)
docs.text:
• Basic test coverage (40-60%)
  • Some unit tests present
  • Manual testing documented

docs.title: Needs Improvement (Below 70%)
docs.text:
• Poor test coverage (<40%)
  • Missing critical tests
  • No testing documentation

docs.title: Excellent (90-100%)
docs.text:
• Version control used effectively
  • Clear commit messages
  • Project structure follows conventions
  • Dependencies managed properly
  • Deployment considerations included

docs.title: Good (80-89%)
docs.text:
• Good use of version control
  • Decent commit messages
  • Reasonable project structure
  • Dependencies mostly managed

docs.title: Satisfactory (70-79%)
docs.text:
• Basic version control usage
  • Some project organization
  • Dependencies present but may be unclear

docs.title: Needs Improvement (Below 70%)
docs.text:
• Poor version control practices
  • Disorganized project structure
  • Dependency issues

docs.title: Overall Project Standards
docs.text:
Minimum Requirements (All Projects): - Project builds and runs without errors - Core functionality works as described - Basic README with setup instructions - At least some test coverage - Clean repository (no temporary files, secrets, etc.)

Level-3 Milestone Additional Requirements: - Demonstrates integration of multiple course concepts - Includes professional development practices - Shows consideration for real-world usage - Portfolio-quality presentation - Evidence of iterative development and improvement

docs.title: Self-Assessment Guide
docs.text:
When evaluating your project, consider:

  1. Would I be comfortable sharing this with potential employers?
  2. Can someone else easily set up and run my project?
  3. Does my code demonstrate the skills I intended to learn?
  4. Have I followed the conventions of my chosen technology stack?
  5. Is my project something I would want to maintain and extend?

docs.title: Getting Feedback
docs.text:
• Use GitHub Discussions for project review requests
  • Participate in community code review sessions
  • Ask specific questions about areas you're uncertain about
  • Share your self-assessment and areas where you want improvement

Remember: The goal is learning and improvement, not perfect scores. Use this rubric to guide your development and identify areas for growth.

docs.title: Zero-to-Pro Achievement Badges
docs.text: Show off your learning progress with these achievement badges!

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
Add to your GitHub profile:

![Zero-to-Pro Level 2](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AyhamJo7/Zero-2-Pro/main/docs/badges/level-2.svg)

Start your badge journey today! 🎯

docs.title: GitHub Classroom Setup Guide
docs.text: Use GitHub Classroom to create structured learning experiences with Zero-to-Pro content for your students, bootcamp, or study group.

docs.title: What is GitHub Classroom?
docs.text: GitHub Classroom helps educators: - Distribute starter code and assignments - Collect student work automatically - Provide feedback through GitHub tools - Track progress across all students - Integrate with LMS systems

docs.title: Quick Setup Steps
docs.text:
1. Request education benefits at education.github.com
  2. Create organization for your classroom
  3. Set up classroom at classroom.github.com
  4. Create assignments based on Zero-to-Pro modules
  5. Share invitation links with students

docs.title: Module-by-Module Assignments
docs.text:
• Separate assignment per Zero-to-Pro module
  • Include starter code and auto-grading
  • Set deadlines for structured progress

docs.title: Track-Based Projects
docs.text:
• One assignment per complete track
  • Focus on milestone projects (Level 3)
  • Allow creative extensions and variations

docs.title: Portfolio Building
docs.text:
• Emphasize Level 3 milestone projects
  • Encourage personal customization
  • Build toward professional portfolios

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• GitHub Classroom Docs
  • Zero-to-Pro Discussions with "classroom" tag

Using GitHub Classroom with Zero-to-Pro? Share your experience to help other educators!

docs.title: Community Progress Dashboard
docs.text:
Last updated: 2024-12-20

This dashboard shows learners who are actively working through the Zero-to-Pro tracks and sharing their progress.

docs.title: 🌱 Getting Started
docs.text:
No active progress reports yet! Be the first to share your journey:

  1. Start a track from our available tracks
  2. Open a Progress Issue using our template
  3. Update your progress as you complete modules
  4. Celebrate milestones with the community

docs.title: How to Share Your Progress
docs.text:
Use the Progress Report issue template to:

  • Set your learning goals
  • Track module completions
  • Share challenges and victories
  • Get support from other learners

docs.title: Benefits of Sharing
docs.text:
• Accountability: Public commitment increases completion rates
  • Community: Connect with others on similar journeys
  • Support: Get help when you're stuck
  • Recognition: Celebrate your achievements

Want to see your progress here? Create a progress issue and start sharing your journey!

docs.title: Reference Solutions Policy
docs.text: This document outlines our approach to providing reference solutions while maintaining the learning experience integrity.

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text: We believe that learning comes from struggling with problems, not from copying solutions. Our policy balances providing guidance with preserving the educational value of each challenge.

docs.title: Public Materials
docs.text:
• Conceptual guides: Architecture patterns, best practices, and design principles
  • Code snippets: Small, focused examples demonstrating specific techniques
  • Debugging help: Common error patterns and troubleshooting guides
  • Tool guides: How to use specific technologies and frameworks

docs.title: Private Repository Solutions
docs.text:
Complete reference implementations are maintained in a private repository accessible only to:

  • Course maintainers and contributors
  • Mentors and teaching assistants
  • Learners who have completed the module (upon request)

docs.title: For Learners
docs.text:
1. Complete the module first: Submit your own solution before requesting references
  2. Request access: Open an issue with the "Reference Request" template
  3. Provide your solution: Link to your completed project for review
  4. Review and compare: Use references to identify improvement opportunities

docs.title: For Mentors
docs.text:
Mentors have access to reference solutions to:

  • Provide consistent code review feedback
  • Identify common learning patterns and gaps
  • Suggest specific improvements without giving away solutions

docs.title: Code Implementation
docs.text:
• Multiple approaches: Different valid solutions to the same problem
  • Progressive complexity: Basic implementation → optimized → production-ready
  • Common variations: Different technology choices and architectural decisions

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Design decisions: Why certain approaches were chosen
  • Trade-offs analysis: Benefits and drawbacks of different solutions
  • Performance considerations: Scalability and optimization insights
  • Testing strategies: Comprehensive test coverage examples

docs.title: Learning Notes
docs.text:
• Common pitfalls: Mistakes learners typically make
  • Extension ideas: How to build upon the basic implementation
  • Real-world connections: How the project relates to industry practices

docs.title: Before Requesting Access
docs.text:
• [ ] Complete your own implementation
  • [ ] Document your approach and design decisions
  • [ ] Identify specific areas where you want feedback
  • [ ] Run tests and validate your solution works

docs.title: Using Reference Solutions
docs.text:
Do: - Compare your approach with reference implementations - Understand the reasoning behind different design choices - Identify optimization opportunities in your code - Use references to improve your next project

Don't: - Copy reference code without understanding it - Submit reference solutions as your own work - Share reference solutions publicly or with other learners - Use references before attempting the problem yourself

docs.title: Quality Standards
docs.text:
Reference solutions must demonstrate:

  • Clean, readable code following language conventions
  • Comprehensive testing with good coverage
  • Clear documentation explaining design decisions
  • Production considerations like error handling and logging

docs.title: Multiple Implementations
docs.text:
We encourage multiple reference solutions showing:

  • Different architectural approaches
  • Various technology stack choices
  • Progressive skill level implementations
  • Different optimization strategies

docs.title: Review Process
docs.text:
All reference solutions undergo:

  1. Technical review for correctness and best practices
  2. Educational review for learning value and clarity
  3. Documentation review for completeness and usefulness
  4. Peer review by other contributors

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text:
reference-solutions/
├── 01-web-development/
│   ├── web-03-spa-api/
│   │   ├── basic-implementation/
│   │   ├── optimized-version/
│   │   └── production-ready/
│   └── challenges/
├── 02-python/
│   └── ...
└── shared/
    ├── patterns/
    └── tools/

docs.title: Maintaining Learning Value
docs.text:
This policy ensures that:

  • Struggle is preserved: Learners must attempt problems independently
  • Growth is supported: References help learners improve and learn
  • Integrity is maintained: Solutions can't be copied without learning
  • Quality is assured: References demonstrate best practices

docs.title: Questions and Clarifications
docs.text:
For questions about this policy, please:

  • Open an issue with the "Policy Question" template
  • Tag relevant maintainers for clarification
  • Participate in community discussions about learning approaches

This policy balances providing support with preserving the educational journey that makes learning valuable.

docs.title: Learning Tracks
docs.text: Choose your learning path based on your goals and interests. Each track takes you from zero to production-ready skills.

docs.title: Git Fundamentals
docs.text:
6 modules across 3 levels

Build production-ready git fundamentals skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: Web Development
docs.text:
5 modules across 5 levels

Build production-ready web development skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
5 modules across 5 levels

Build production-ready python skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: Java
docs.text:
5 modules across 5 levels

Build production-ready java skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: Go
docs.text:
5 modules across 5 levels

Build production-ready go skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: AI/ML
docs.text:
5 modules across 5 levels

Build production-ready ai/ml skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: Cyber Security
docs.text:
5 modules across 5 levels

Build production-ready cyber security skills through hands-on learning.

docs.title: How Tracks Work
docs.text:
Each track follows a proven learning progression:

  • Level 0: Orientation and setup
  • Level 1: Foundation concepts
  • Level 2: Core practical skills
  • Level 3: Real-world project milestone
  • Level 4: Advanced production techniques

docs.title: 00 — Git Path
docs.text: Modules for 00 — Git Path grouped by level. Links go to the repo file.

docs.title: Level 0 — Zero
docs.text: • Git from Absolute Zero: Concepts & Setup (git-01-intro)

docs.title: Level 1 — Foundations
docs.text:
• Branches & Merges: Fast-forward, Three-way (git-03-branches-merges)
  • Local Basics: init, status, add, commit, log (git-02-first-commit)

docs.title: Level 2 — Core
docs.text:
• Rebase Safely: interactive rebase, fixups, autosquash (git-05-rebase-conflicts)
  • Remotes & GitHub: clone, fetch, pull, push, PR (git-04-remotes-github)
  • Time Travel: log formats, blame, bisect, tags (git-06-history-tools)

docs.title: 01 — Web Development
docs.text: Modules for 01 — Web Development grouped by level. Links go to the repo file.

docs.title: Level 0 — Zero
docs.text: • From Zero: How the Web Works (Client/Server, HTTP, HTML/CSS) (web-00-orientation)

docs.title: Level 1 — Foundations
docs.text: • Foundations: Modern JavaScript + DOM Essentials (web-01-foundations-js)

docs.title: Level 2 — Core
docs.text: • Core Skills: API Basics + Persistence + Auth Concepts (web-02-core-fullstack)

docs.title: Level 3 — Projects
docs.text: • Milestone: SPA + API with Auth and Tests (web-03-project-spa-api)

docs.title: Level 4 — Advanced
docs.text: • Advanced: Web Performance & Observability (web-04-advanced)

docs.title: 02 — Python
docs.text: Modules for 02 — Python grouped by level. Links go to the repo file.

docs.title: Level 0 — Zero
docs.text: • From Zero: Install Python, Virtual Envs, and First Script (py-00-setup)

docs.title: Level 1 — Foundations
docs.text: • Foundations: Types, Control Flow, Functions, Modules (py-01-foundations)

docs.title: Level 2 — Core
docs.text: • Core Skills: Packaging, Testing (pytest), Logging, CLI (py-02-core-tooling)

docs.title: Level 3 — Projects
docs.text: • Milestone: CLI Utility with Tests and Release (py-03-project-cli)

docs.title: Level 4 — Advanced
docs.text: • Advanced: Async IO, Concurrency, and Profiling (py-04-advanced)

docs.title: 03 — Java
docs.text: Modules for 03 — Java grouped by level. Links go to the repo file.

docs.title: Level 2 — Core

docs.title: Level 3 — Projects

docs.title: Level 4 — Advanced

docs.title: 04 — Go
